entry.title: Binion Hoard (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that charges of murder and grand larceny followed the theft of the Binion Hoard (coin pictured), which was valued at US$4 million in 1998?

entry.title: Germany at Eurovision in 2020 (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Slovenian-born singer Ben Dolic was set to represent Germany at Eurovision in 2020?

entry.title: Phoenician sanctuary of Kharayeb (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the deity of the Phoenician sanctuary of Kharayeb remains unidentified due to the absence of names of specific gods in unearthed inscriptions?

entry.title: Maggie Tokuda-Hall (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Scholastic requested Maggie Tokuda-Hall remove the phrase "virulent racism" from the Author's Note in Love in the Library, a children's book about Japanese-American internment camps?

entry.title: Catholic Tübingen school (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ...that in 1819, members of the Catholic Tübingen school first published the Theologische Quartalschrift, which remains in print as the oldest journal of Catholic theology in the world?

entry.title: Tanner Brown (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that American Tanner Brown went from being a walk-on to a semifinalist for the Lou Groza Award as the best college placekicker in the nation?

entry.title: unus testis, nullus testis (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the unus testis, nullus testis rule has been criticised because it makes convictions in rape cases very difficult?

entry.title: Ian Heslop (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that butterfly collector Ian Heslop was once required to supervise an execution?
